title.children: Loved ones release statements honouring men who died in Taipan chopper crash

title.children: Vendors back in control: Brisbane one of the top cities when it comes to growth in housing prices

image.altText: A dark haired woman pushing against a white wall with both hands.

items.synopsis: The most common disorders for women were depression, a specific phobia and post-traumatic stress disorder. For men it was depression, a specific phobia and alcohol abuse.

title.children: Half the population will experience a mental health disorder by 75, global study reveals

image.altText: A desert kurrajong tree sits against a purple night sky.

items.synopsis: Against the dry, arid landscapes of west and central Australia, these trees not only catch your eye, but are a source of food and water and can point you in the right direction if you're lost.

title.children: The desert kurrajong looks like a child's drawing of a tree, but in the outback it can be a lifesaver

image.altText: the silouhette of a young woman sititng on a bed

items.synopsis: State government data shows 104 vulnerable children spent nearly 2,000 nights combined in commercial accommodation between January and June this year.

title.children: 'Simply unacceptable': More than half a million spent putting up vulnerable Queensland kids in hotels

image.altText: A scene of streets leading to the ocean on Palm Island, North Queensland.

items.synopsis: Police say the woman was dragged from her wheelchair by two dogs and bitten multiple times on her neck, face and arms, in the remote Indigenous community of Palm Island off the North Queensland coast.

title.children: Woman loses ear in vicious island dog attack

image.altText: On a shelf of coral, some corals are a stark white colour.

image.altText: Angus Cloud, dressed in a purple top, clasps his hands together on the red carpet.

image.altText: Dr Paul Giacomin inspects a parasitic worm often found in dogs.

title.children: Live hookworms in the gut may help people at risk of type 2 diabetes, study finds

image.altText: A destroyed building in Ukraine's Luhansk region.

items.synopsis: So far, the Ukrainians appear to have been able to minimise Russian gains in Luhansk. But what does this new Russian offensive tell us about Russia's strategy and the trajectory of the war, asks Mick Ryan.

title.children: What Russia's 'forgotten offensive' tells us about the trajectory of war in Ukraine

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says Australia's fight against inflation is not yet over as the Reserve Bank weighs a possible interest rate hike at its meeting. Follow live.

title.children: Chalmers says Australia making 'welcome progress' in inflation fight but 'not there yet' as RBA weighs possible rate hike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest CoreLogic data shows house prices rose by 0.7% in July, but the housing market may be losing steam ahead of the spring selling season. It was the fifth-straight month property prices rose across Australia, with capital cities seeing stronger growth than regional areas, however CoreLogic noted that there had been a "flow of new listings" hitting the market. Sydney has seen a near 10% rise in fresh listings compared to this time last year, and 18% above its five-year average, CoreLogic's research director Tim Lawless said. "An increased flow of new listings provides more choice and may be working to reduce some of the urgency felt among prospective buyers," he said. But the slowdown in the overall growth rate of property prices has been driven by a fall in premium housing markets, and Mr Lawless said that might be indicative of a wider weakness approaching the market in the coming months. "With total stock levels still low and selling conditions reasonably strong, it may be the case that more home owners are picking current market conditions as a good time to sell, rather than waiting until spring when stock levels might be higher, creating more competition among vendors," he said. "Another possibility is that we are seeing the first signs of motivated selling as the rapid rate-hiking cycle catches up with household balance sheets." You can read the full story from my colleague, business reporter Michael Janda below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is the property market beginning to lose steam after its recent rebound?

featuredLink.title: House price recovery slows as listings rise and regional markets stagnate

house prices rose by 0.7% in July
, but the
housing market may be losing steam

It was the
fifth-straight month property prices rose across Australia
, with capital cities seeing stronger growth than regional areas, however CoreLogic noted that there had been a "flow of new listings" hitting the market.
Sydney has seen a near
10% rise in fresh listings
compared to this time last year, and 18% above its five-year average, CoreLogic's research director Tim Lawless said.
"An increased flow of new listings provides more choice and
may be working to reduce some of the urgency
felt among prospective buyers," he said.
But the slowdown in the overall growth rate of property prices has been driven by a
fall in premium housing markets
, and Mr Lawless said that
might be indicative of a wider weakness
approaching the market in the coming months.
"With total stock levels still low and selling conditions reasonably strong,
it may be the case that more home owners are picking current market conditions as a good time to sell
, rather than waiting until spring when stock levels might be higher, creating more competition among vendors," he said.
"Another possibility is that we are seeing
the first signs of motivated selling as the rapid rate-hiking cycle
catches up with household balance sheets."
You can read the full story from my colleague,
business reporter Michael Janda
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If money markets are anything to go by, they're weighing in favour of a rate pause by the RBA today, currently factoring in an 86% chance of a freeze by the central bank at today's meeting. But even though the RBA will give us more insight into whether its aggressive streak of rate hikes are coming to an end as inflation slows, some economists are warning that it could begin to rear its head again in the near future. You can listen back to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan's full take below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets predicting RBA rate 'freeze' will continue at 4.1 per cent

children.content: If money markets are anything to go by, they're weighing in favour of a
rate pause by the RBA today
, currently factoring in an 86% chance of a freeze by the central bank at today's meeting.
But even though the RBA will give us more insight into
whether its aggressive streak of rate hikes are coming to an end
as inflation slows, some economists are warning that it could begin to rear its head again in the near future.
You can listen back to
senior business correspondent Peter Ryan's
full take below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has just been speaking to RN Breakfast ahead of today's RBA meeting. Host Patricia Karvelas asked him whether he thought Australians could cope with another interest rate rise. Chalmers was wary of answering, maintaining that the central bank must act independently, but said that the fight against high inflation wasn't over despite it showing signs that it was moderating. " Australians are under the pump. We are seeing the impact of the rate rises which are already in the system," he said. "We are making welcome progress in the fight against inflation, but we're not there yet, and the Reserve Bank will weigh up the fact that inflation is moderating. "We had a soft retail trade figure last week. "They will weigh that all up in the usual way and they'll come to a decision whether rates go up or not." Karvelas pushed Chalmers for an answer on whether he thought Australians could handle a rate rise after today's meeting, to which he acknowledged the past rises were hurting people. "Put it this way, Patricia, the rate rises which are already in the system have made life harder for people. I mean, that's self evident," he said. "And, you know … I've said probably the last half a dozen times that you and I have spoken that we understand that whether it's inflation, which has been higher than we'd like for longer than we'd like, whether it is these interest rate rises over the last, since before the election last year, whether it's the global economic uncertainty, it's putting people under pressure and slowing our economy already, we're already seeing the impact of the rate rises, which are in the system. "We're seeing that in a heap of data that we've been getting in the last few weeks or months. The Reserve Bank will weigh that up, and they'll come to a decision independently."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We are making progress in the fight against inflation but we're not there yet', Chalmers says
